Chapter 4. Duality Theory

 

4.1 Motivation

We associate a price variable (or Lagrange multiplier) with each constraint and start searching for prices under which the presence or absence of the constraints does not affect the optimal cost.

 

A. The primal problem in standard form

Consider a linear problem in standard form:

minimizecTxsubject toAx=bx≥0,

which we call the primal problem, and assume that an optimal solution x∗ exists.

We introduce a relaxed problem with a price vector p∈Rm:

minimizecTx+pT(b−Ax)subject tox≥0.

Then the optimal cost of the relaxed problem

g(p)=minx≥0[cTx+pT(b−Ax)]≤cTx∗+pT(b−Ax∗)=cTx∗

is a lower bound for the optimal cost cTx∗ for all p. Moreover,

g(p)=pTb+minx≥0(cT−pTA)x=pTb+{0,if cT−pTA≥0T−∞,otherwise.

The dual problem searches for the tightest possible lower bound, maxp∈Rmg(p):

maximizepTbsubject topTA≤cT.

 

B. The primal problem in general form

Consider the primal problem in general form:

minimizecTxsubject toAx≥b,

which is equivalent to the problem:

minimizecTxsubject toAx−s=bs≥0.

(Warning) The equality Ax−s=b can be written in the form [A|−Im][xs]=b, and thus the dual constraints become pT[A|−Im]≤[cT|0mT]; in other words, pTA≤cT and p≥0. However, s≥0 but x is free in this problem.

Actually, the optimal cost for the relaxed problem is

g(p)=minx∈Rn,s≥0[cTx+pT(b−Ax+s)]=pTb+minx∈Rn(cT−pTA)x+mins≥0pTs=pTb+{0,if cT−pTA=0T−∞,otherwise+{0,if p≥0−∞,otherwise.

Therefore, the dual problem is

maximizepTbsubject topTA=cTp≥0.

Notice that if the equality is replaced to Ax+s=b (in the case of Ax≤b), then the dual constraints should be replaced to p≤0.

 

4.2 The dual problem

Given a primal problem with the structure shown on the left, its dual is defined to be the maximization problem shown on the right:

minimizecTxmaximizepTbsubject toaiTx≥bi,subject topi≥0,i∈M1,aiTx≤bi,pi≤0,i∈M2,aiTx=bi,pi free,i∈M3,xj≥0,pTAj≤cjj∈N1,xj≤0,pTAj≥cjj∈N2,xj free,pTAj=cjj∈N3.

Theorem 4.1 If we transform the dual into an equivalent minimization problem and then form its dual, we obtain a problem equivalent to the original problem. In other words, "the dual of the dual is the primal."

Theorem 4.2 Suppose that we have transformed a linear programming problem Π1 to another linear programming problem Π2, by a sequence of transformations of the following types:

  1. Replace a free variable with the difference of two nonnegative variables.

  2. Replace an inequality constraint by an equality constraint involving a nonnegative slack variable.

  3. If some row of A in a feasible standard form problem is a linear combination of the other rows, eliminate the corresponding equality constraint.

Then, the duals of Π1 and Π2 are equivalent, i.e., they are either both infeasible, or they have the same optimal cost.

 

4.3 The duality theorem

A primal and its dual can be stated more compactly, in matrix notation. In standard form,

minimizecTxmaximizepTbsubject toAx=bsubject topTA≤cT,x≥0,

and in general form,

minimizecTxmaximizepTbsubject toAx≥b,subject topTA=cTp≥0.

For x∈Rn and p∈Rm, we define

ui≡pi(aiTx−bi)andvj≡(cj−pTAj)xj.

Since ∑iui=pT(Ax−b) and ∑jvj=(cT−pTA)x​, we have

∑iui+∑jvj=cTx−pTb.

Let x and p be feasible solutions to the primal and the dual, respectively. In standard form, ui=0 and vj≥0. On the other hand, in general form, ui≥0 and vj=0. In both cases, ∑iui+∑jvj≥0.

Theorem 4.3 (Weak duality) If x is a feasible solution to the primal problem and p is a feasible solution to the dual problem, then pTb≤cTx​.

Corollary 4.1 (a) If the optimal cost in the primal is −∞, the dual problem must be infeasible. (b) If the optimal cost in the dual is ∞, the primal problem must be infeasible.

Corollary 4.2 Let x and p be feasible solutions to the primal and the dual, respectively. If pTb=cTx, then x and p are optimal solutions to the primal and the dual, respectively.

Theorem 4.4 (Strong duality) If a linear programming problem has an optimal solution, then so does its dual, and the respective optimal costs are equal.

Proof. (Case 1) Consider the standard form problem: Minimize cTx subject to Ax=b and x≥0.

  1. Assume that the rows of A are linearly independent and that there exists an optimal solution.

  2. Apply the simplex method to this problem. As long as cycling is avoided, the simplex method terminates with an optimal solution x∗ and an optimal basis B.

  3. When the simplex method terminates, the reduced costs must be nonnegative, i.e., c¯T=cT−cBTB−1A≥0T.

  4. Define pT≡cBTB−1​. Then pTA≤cT, which shows that p is a feasible solution to the dual problem: Maximize pTb subject to pTA≤cT.

  5. In addition, pTb=cBTB−1b=cBTxB∗=cTx∗, since x∗​ is a basic feasible solution.

  6. By Corollary 4.2, p​ is an optimal solution to the dual, and the optimal dual cost is equal to the optimal primal cost.

(Case 2) Consider the general form problem Π1 that has an optimal solution. We first transform Π1 into an equivalent standard form problem Π2 with the same optimal cost, and in which the rows of A are linearly independent.

In a linear programming problem, exactly one of the following three possibilities will occur:

  1. (Finite optimum) There is an optimal solution.

  2. (Unbounded) The problem is unbounded; that is, the optimal cost is −∞ (for primal problems) or ∞ (for dual problems).

  3. (Infeasible) The problem is infeasible.

This leads to nine possible combinations for the primal and the dual.

 

Complementary slackness

Theorem 4.5 (Complementary slackness) Let x and p be feasible solutions to the primal and the dual problem, respectively. Then x and p are optimal if and only if

ui≡pi(aiTx−bi)=0for 1≤i≤m,vj≡(cj−pTAj)xj=0for 1≤j≤n.

Proof. Recall that, for primal feasible x and dual feasible p, we have ui≥0 and vj≥0 for all i and j. Moreover, cTx−pTb=∑iui+∑jvj≥0.

(⇒) By the strong duality theorem, if x and p are optimal, then cTx=pTb, which implies that ui=vj=0 for all i and j. (⇐) follows from Corollary 4.2.

A. In standard form

We may assume that the rows of A are linearly independent. (See Example 4.3.)

The first complementary slackness condition is automatically satisfied by every feasible solution x to a primal problem in standard form, since Ax=b. Thus it gives no information on p.

However, if x is a nondegenerate optimal basic feasible solution, then the second complementary slackness conditions determine a unique solution pT=cBTB−1 to the dual problem, since xj>0 for all basic variables j∈B.

B. In general form

The first complementary slackness condition implies that pi=0 for all non-active constraints aiTx≥bi.

If x is a nondegenerate optimal basic feasible solution, then there are n linearly independent active constraints so that the rank of A is n. Therefore, a unique solution to the dual problem is determined by pTA=cT or ATp=c.

C. Degenerate case

On the other hand, if we are given a degenerate optimal basic feasible solution to the primal, then the complementary slackness may be of very little help in determining an optimal solution to the dual problem.

 

A geometric view

Consider the primal problem in general form. Let I⊆{1,…,m} such that (1) |I|=n and (2) ai for i∈I are linearly independent rows of A. Then the system aiTx=bi for i∈I has a unique solution xI, which is a basic solution to the primal problem. We assume that xI is nondegenerate, that is, aiTx≠bi for all i∉I​.

Let p∈Rm (not necessarily dual feasible), and consider what is required for xI and p to be optimal solutions. We need:

  1. aiTxI>bi for all i∉I (primal feasibility),

  2. pi=0 for all i∉I (complementary slackness),

  3. pTA=cT​ or ATp=c (dual feasibility),

  4. p≥0m (dual feasibility).

From (2) and (3), we have a system ∑i∈Ipiai=c, and it has a unique solution pI, since ai for i∈I are n linearly independent. For pI to be dual feasible, we also need pI≥0n​.

Therefore, if (2) is satisfied, pI is feasible if and only if c is a nonnegative linear combination of ai for i∈I.

 

4.4 Optimal dual variables as marginal costs

Consider the primal problem in standard form. We assume the rows of A are linearly independent and that there is a nondegenerate basic feasible solution x∗​ which is optimal.

Let B be the corresponding basis matrix. Then xB∗=B−1b>0m by nondegeneracy. Now replace b by b+d for a sufficiently small perturbation vector d∈Rm so that B−1(b+d)>0m.

  • The same basis B leads to a basic feasible solution of the perturbed problem as well.

  • Perturbing b has no effect on the reduced costs c¯=cT−cBTB−1A.

  • By the optimality of x∗ in the original problem, c¯≥0 and this establishes that the same basis B is optimal for the perturbed problem as well.

  • The optimal cost in the perturbed problem is cBTB−1(b+d)=pT(b+d), where pT=cBTB−1 is an optimal solution to the dual problem. Therefore, a small change of d in b results in a change of pTd in the optimal cost.

We conclude that each component pi of the optimal dual vector can be interpreted as the marginal cost (or shadow price) per unit increase of the i-th requirement bi.

 

4.5 Standard form problems and the dual simplex method

We concentrate on the case where the primal problem is in standard form.

Note that the primal optimality condition c¯T≡cT−cBTB−1A≥0T is the same as the dual feasibility condition pTA≤cT by letting pT=cBTB−1.

  • We can thus think of the simplex method as an algorithm that maintains primal feasibility xB=B−1b≥0 and works towards dual feasibility c¯T≥0T. A method with this property is generally called a primal algorithm.

  • An alternative is to start with a dual feasible solution (satisfying c¯T≥0T) and work towards primal feasibility xB≥0. A method of this type is called a dual algorithm.

 

The dual simplex method

Consider a problem in standard form, under the assumption that the rows of A are linearly independent. Let B be a basis matrix, consisting of m linearly independent columns of A​, and consider the (same) corresponding tableau

  • We do not require xB=B−1b≥0, which means that x is a basic solution (B−1ABi=ei for 1≤i≤m and xj=0 for j∉B; see Theorem 2.4), but not necessarily feasible.

  • However, we assume that c¯≥0, equivalently, pTA≤cT, and we have a dual feasible solution p.

  • The dual cost is pTb=cBTB−1b=cBTxB​, which is the negative of the entry at the upper left corner of the tableau.

  • If xB=B−1b≥0 happens to hold, we also have a primal feasible solution x​ with the same cost, and optimal solutions to both problems have been found.

  • If xBi<0 for some 1≤i≤m, we perform a change of basis as follows.

    • We find some 1≤l≤m such that xBl<0 and consider the l-th row of the tableau, called the pivot row (xBl,v1,…,vn), where vi is the l-th component of B−1Ai.

    • For each i with vi<0 (if exists), let j be an index for which this ratio is smallest, that is, vj<0 and

      c¯j|vj|=mini∣vi<0c¯i|vi|.

      We call vj the pivot element. Note that xj must be a nonbasic variable. (∵ B−1Aj=ei≥0 if j=Bi is a basic variable.)

    • We then perform a change of basis: column Aj enters the basis and column ABl exits. This change of basis (or pivot) is effected exactly as in the primal simplex method.

An iteration of the dual simplex method

  1. A typical iteration starts with the simplex tableau associated with B and with c¯≥0.

  2. Examine xB=B−1b in the zeroth column of the tableau.

    • If xB≥0, we have an optimal basic feasible solution and the algorithm terminates.

    • Otherwise, choose an exiting index 1≤l≤m such that xBl<0.

  3. Consider the l-th row (the pivot row) of the tableau, (xBl,v1,…,vn).

    • If vi≥0 for all 1≤i≤n, then the optimal dual cost is ∞ and the algorithm terminates.

  4. Otherwise, choose an entering index 1≤j≤n such that c¯j|vj|=mini∣vi<0c¯i|vi|.

  5. (Elementary row operations) Add to each row of the tableau a constant multiple of the l-th row (the pivot row) so that vj (the pivot element) becomes one and all other entries of the pivot column become zero.

The total computational effort per iteration is O(mn).

If the dual simplex method is initialized so that every column of the tableau is lexicographically positive, and if the following lexicographic pivoting rule is used, the method terminates in a finite number of steps.

Lexicographic pivoting rule for the dual simplex method

  1. Choose an exiting row l arbitrarily, as long as xBl<0, to be the pivot row.

  2. Determine the entering index j as follows.

    • For each column with vi<0, divide all entries in the column by |vi|, and then choose the lexicographically smallest column.

    • If there is a tie between several lexicographically smallest columns, choose the one with the smallest index.

 

The geometry of the dual simplex method

It may be tempting to say that the dual simplex method is simply the primal simplex method applied to the dual. Notice that, however, the dual problem is not in standard form.

 

Duality and degeneracy

Definition 2.10 A basic solution x∈Rn is said to be degenerate if more than n of the constraints are active at x.

Definition 2.11 Let P={x∈Rb∣Ax=b,x≥0} be a polyhedron in standard form where A is an m×n matrix. A basic solution x is called degenerate if more than n−m components of x are zero.

Any basis matrix B leads to an associated dual basic solution given by pT=cBTB−1. At this basic solution, the dual constraint pTAj≤cj is active if and only if the reduced cost c¯j=cj−cBTB−1Aj=0. Since p∈Rm, dual degeneracy amounts to having more than m​ reduced costs that are zero.

Notice that the reduced costs of m basic variables must be zero. Thus dual degeneracy is obtained whenever there exists a nonbasic variable j∉B such that c¯j=0.

 

Summary for standard form problems

  1. Every basis matrix B determines a basic solution xB=B−1b (and xj=0 for j∉B) to the primal, but also a corresponding basic solution pT=cBTB−1 to the dual.

  2. This dual basic solution is feasible if and only if c¯T=cT−pTA≥0T​.

  3. Under this dual basic solution, the reduced cost c¯j=0 corresponds to the active constraint pTAj=cj​ in the dual problem.

  4. This dual basic solution is degenerate if and only if c¯j=0 for some nonbasic variable j∉B​.

 

Duality relationships between degeneracy and multiplicity [Linear and Integer Optimization, Theory and Practice 3E, p.223]

4.6 Farkas' lemma and linear inequalities

Suppose that we wish to determine whether a given system of linear inequalities is infeasible.

Theorem 4.6 (Farkas' lemma) Let A be an m×n matrix and let b∈Rm. Then, exactly one of the following two alternatives holds:

  1. There exists some x≥0 such that Ax=b.

  2. There exists some p∈Rm such that pTA≥0T and pTb<0​.

Proof. Suppose (1) holds. If pTA≥0T then pTb=pT(Ax)≥0, which is a contradiction to (2).

Suppose (1) does not hold and consider the pair of problems

minimize(−0)TxmaximizepTbsubject toAx=bsubject topTA≤(−0)T,x≥0,

or, equivalently,

maximize0Txminimize(−p)Tbsubject toAx=bsubject to(−p)TA≥0T,x≥0.

The (left) primal is infeasible so that the (right) dual is unbounded (the optimal cost is −∞) since p=0 is a dual feasible solution. Therefore, there exists some −p with (−p)Tb<0​​.

 

Geometric illustration of Farkas' lemma

The existence of x≥0 satisfying Ax=b is the same as that b is expressed as a nonnegative linear combination of the columns of A. Otherwise, we expect intuitively that we can find p and an associated hyperplane {z∣pTz=0} that separates b from the set {Ax∣x≥0}. (See Section 4.7.)

Corollary 4.3 Let A1,…,An,b∈Rm. Suppose that any p∈Rm that satisfies pTAi≥0 for all 1≤i≤n must also satisfy pTb≥0. Then b can be expressed as a nonnegative linear combination of A1,…,An​.

Theorem 4.7 Suppose that the system of linear inequalities Ax≤b has at least one solution, and let d be some scalar. Then, the following are equivalent:

  1. Every feasible solution to the system Ax≤b satisfies cTx≤d.

  2. There exists some p≥0 such that pTA=cT and pTb≤d​.

Proof. Consider the pair of problems

minimize(−c)TxmaximizepTbsubject toAx≤bsubject topTA=(−c)Tp≤0.

(⇒) The primal is feasible by assumption, and it has an optimal solution x∗ by (1) with the optimal cost (−c)Tx∗≥−d. By the strong duality, the dual problem also has an optimal solution p∗≤0 and (p∗)Tb=(−c)Tx∗≥−d. Then −p∗≥0 is what we want to find.

(⇐) By (2) we have a dual feasible solution −p≤0 and it satisfies that −d≤(−p)Tb≤−cTx for all primal feasible solutions x​ by the weak duality.

 

Clark's theorem

Alternative Farkas' lemma Exactly one of the following two alternatives holds:

  1. There exists some x≥0 such that Ax≤b.

  2. There exists some p∈Rm such that pTA≥0T, pTb<0, and p≥0.

Proof. Notice that Ax≤b, x≥0 is feasible if and only if Ax+s=b, x≥0, s≥0.

Clark's theorem [Clark, 1961] Consider the following pair of the primal and the dual problems:

minimizecTxmaximizepTbsubject toAx≥bsubject top≥0x≥0,pTA≤cT.

Unless both problems are infeasible, at least one of them must have an unbounded feasible set.

Proof. Suppose that the primal and the dual are feasible. Alternative Farkas' lemma tells us exact one of the following system holds.

  1. There exists some p≥0 such that ATp≤−1n.

  2. There exists some x∈Rn such that xTAT≥0T, xT(−1n)<0, and x≥0.

If (2) holds, let x∗≠0 be a feasible solution to (2) and let x be a feasible solution to the primal problem. Then A(x+λx∗)=Ax+λAx∗≥b for all λ>0​. It follows that the primal has an unbounded feasible set.

On the other hand, if (1) holds, let p∗≠0 be a feasible solution to (1) and let p be a feasible solution to the dual problem. Then (p+λp∗)TA=pTA+λ(p∗)TA≤cT−λ1nT≤cT for all λ>0. It follows that the dual has an unbounded feasible set.

 

4.7 From separating hyperplanes to duality

Theorem 4.11 (Separating hyperplane theorem) Let S≠∅⊆Rn be closed convex and let x∗∉S. Then there exists some c∈Rn such that cTx∗<cTx for all x∈S.

 

Separating hyperplane theorem implies Farkas' lemma

Proof. Suppose (1) does not hold. Then b∉S={Ax∣x≥0}⊆Rm and S is a nonempty closed convex set. By the separating hyperplane theorem, there exists p∈Rm such that pTb<pTy for all y∈S​.

  • Since A0=0∈S, we have pTb<pT0=0​.

  • Since each column Ai=Aei∈S, we have λAi∈S so that pTb<λpTAi ⇒ 1λpTb<pTAi for all λ>0. It follows that pTAi≥0 for all 1≤i≤m by taking the limit as λ→∞.

 

Farkas' lemma implies the strong duality theorem

We only provide the proof for the linear problem in general form:

minimizecTxmaximizepTbsubject toAx≥b,subject topTA=cTp≥0.

Suppose that the primal has an optimal solution x∗. We will show that the dual problem also has a feasible solution with the same cost. Then Theorem 4.4 (Strong duality) follows from Corollary 4.2.

Proof. Let I={i∣aiTx∗=bi} be the set of indices of the constraints that are active at x∗​. We claim that any d that satisfies aiTd≥0 for all i∈I, must also satisfy cTd≥0.

(∵) If i∈I, then aiTd≥0 ⇒ aiT(x∗+ϵd)≥aiTx∗=bi for ϵ>0. On the other hand, if i∉I, then aiTx∗>bi ⇒ aiT(x∗+ϵd)>bi for sufficiently small ϵ>0. Therefore, x∗+ϵd is a feasible solution for sufficiently small ϵ>0. The optimality of x∗ implies that cT(x∗+ϵd)≥cTx∗ and thus cTd≥0​.

By Farkas' lemma (Corollary 4.3), c can be expressed as a nonnegative linear combination of ai for i∈I, so that c=∑i∈Ipiai for pi≥0. For i∉I, let pi=0. Then p is a dual feasible solution, i.e., p≥0 and pTA=cT. Moreover,

pTb=∑i∈Ipibi=∑i∈Ipi(aiTx∗)=cTx∗,

which shows that the dual cost of p is the same as the optimal primal cost.

 

4.8 Cones and extreme rays

Cones

Definition 4.1 A set C⊂Rn is a cone if λx∈C for all λ≥0 and for all x∈C​.

Notice that every nonempty cone contains 0. (∵ If x∈C, we must have 0=0x∈C​.) A polyhedron of the form {x∈Rn∣Ax≥0}​​ is a nonempty cone and is called a polyhedral cone.

Note that any x≠0 in a polyhedral cone C is not an extreme point so that the only possible extreme point is 0. If 0 is indeed an extreme point, we say that the cone is pointed.

Theorem 4.12 Let C={x∈Rn∣Ax≥0} be a polyhedral cone. Then the following are equivalent:

  1. 0 is an extreme point of C.

  2. C does not contain a line. (See Theorem 2.6.)

  3. A has n​ linearly independent rows (or 0 is a basic feasible solution.)

 

Rays and recession cones

Let P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} be a nonempty polyhedron. The recession cone at y∈P is defined by

{d∈Rn∣y+λd∈P for all λ≥0},

and it is the same as the polyhedral cone {d∈Rn∣Ad≥0}. (⊇) is trivial. (⊆) If aiTd<0 for some i, then aiT(y+λd)→−∞ as λ→∞. This shows that the recession cone is independent of the choice of y. The nonzero elements of the recession cone are called the rays of P.

For the case of a nonempty polyhedron P={x∈Rn∣Ax=b,x≥0} in standard form, the recession cone is {d∈Rn∣Ad=0,d≥0}.

 

Extreme rays

Definition 4.2 (a) A x≠0 of a polyhedral cone C⊆Rn is called an extreme ray if there are n−1 linearly independent constraints that are active at x​.

(b) An extreme ray of the recession cone associated with a nonempty polyhedron P is also called an extreme ray of P.

 

Characterization of unbounded linear programming problems

Theorem 4.13 Consider the problem of minimizing cTx over a pointed polyhedral cone C={x∈Rn∣Ax≥0}. The optimal cost is equal to −∞ if and only if some extreme ray d∈C satisfies cTd<0​.

Proof. (⇐) is trivial. (⇒) By assumption, there exists some x∈C whose cost cTx=−1. In particular, the polyhedron P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥0,cTx=−1} is nonempty. Since C is pointed, the rows of A span Rn so that P has at least one extreme point, say d. At d, we have n linearly independent active constraints, which means that n−1 linearly independent constraints from Ax≥0 must be active. It follows that d is an extreme ray of C.

Theorem 4.14 Consider the problem of minimizing cTx over P={x∈Rn∣Ax≥b} in general form. Assume that P has at least one extreme point. The optimal cost is equal to −∞ if and only if some extreme ray d∈P satisfies cTd<0​.

Proof. (⇐) is trivial. (⇒​) Consider the two problems:

maximizepTbmaximizepT0subject topTA=cTsubject topTA=cTp≥0,p≥0.

If the primal problem is unbounded, the (left) dual problem is infeasible. Then the right problem is also infeasible so that the associated primal problem of minimizing cTx subject to Ax≥0 is unbounded, since 0 is a feasible solution.

Since the primal feasible set has at least one extreme point by assumption, the rows of A span Rn. It follows that the recession cone {x∣Ax≥0} is pointed and, by Theorem 4.13, there exists an extreme ray d of the recession cone satisfying cTd<0. This is an extreme ray of the feasible set.

 

The unboundedness criterion in the simplex method

If we have a standard form problem in which the optimal cost is −∞, the simplex method provides us at termination with an extreme ray, the j-th basic direction d≥0 satisfying Ad=0, since dB=−B−1Aj, dj=1, and di=0 for other nonbasic indices i≠j.
